div1.p: Connor discusses his theories regarding the origins of yellow fever.

Connor
My dear Doctor Carter:
div1.p:
I am returning your MSS. "the History on Place
of origin of Yellow Fever', Have read it as you suggest-
ed, first with the notes and again without the notes. I
have done this not once but several times.

This history as you have compiled it and your
analysis of the data is intensely interesting and ill-
uminating and probably as definite as such a a work can
be at this time. Conclusive evidence indicating the
place of origin of yellow fever or the evolution of
this infection into a separate entity is probably con
tained in the carving and picture writings on the mon-
uments scattered through out Mexico and Central America.
Doctor Marinez once told me that this is his opin-
ion also.

I should be inclined to accept as yellow fever the
cases reported by Bernal Diaz occuring in his command
in Mexico city in which the vomiting of ‘blood and mud’
was noted as a symptom. It is true that these cases
may have been pneumonia but the instances have been
rare where pneumonia with the vomiting of blood have
taken on epidemic characteristics even in Mexico city.
The reading of this particular part of the MSS. would
lead me to think that Diaz was walking away from an
epidemic of yellow fever rather than pnuemonia. Again
I do not think that you can ignore the fact that there
may have been an epidemic of yellow fever in Mexico
City during a long hot summer. The only transmisor of
the Leptospira Icteroides is present there to-day and
was there in all probabilities when the conquistadores
visited the city.

We are probably justified in assuming that the
yellow fever infection has not undergone any marked
change in its symptom-complex in the last five hundred
or thousands years and to-day we are observing, if the
report of Doctor White re- yellow fever in Cucuta is
correct, this infection lying dormant, that is in a very
mild form, in a large city for nearly ten years without
having attracted attention to it and only then when the
infection invaded another city. Could not this same
thing have happened in Mexico during the Aztec reign?
I think it could.

From the little that we know of the habits of the
ancient Mexican peoples it appears clear to me that
-2-
they only interested themselves in affairs of disease when an infection
had taken on epidemic proportions. This is not unlike the attitude that
we note to-day in certain section of our own country.

Only last year in Panuco the mild and moderately severe cases
of what later proved to be yellow fever were called paludismo hemmoragica
and had been so-called for years and would in probability have con-
tinued to be so classified if we had not studied the infection and place
it in its proper catagoria. The same thing may have happened in the
time of the aztecs. For this reason I do not think that a definite state-
ment can be made one way or the other nor are deductions sound when based
on the evidence at hand at this time.

As a side issue to the Panuco outbreak- we were
inclined to think at the begining of the epidemic that it was not
yellow fever because the white foreigners were not coming down but here we over
looked the fact that the white foreigners are nearly all oil men working in
the camps during the day and only coming into the key center (panuco) at
night when the ‘steg’ to say the least is only passively active. This obse-
ervation is proven to a certain extent by finding that the first two white
foreigners to be infected were oil men who hade lived in Panuco during the
day-light hours for one week before coming down sick. Here in Mexico the
aedes egypti is essentially a day-biter. The white foreigners really played
a very small part in the last epidemic here. Might not there have been a similar
state of affairs present during the early years of the conquistadores?

Now let us look at what occured in Texas last year. There was an epi-
demic of dengue, so-called, in which there was vomiting of digested blood
in many cases and in certain areas the death rate was high, so high in fact
that your own service became suspicious. Fortunately the winter came on
and checked the spread of the infection.

It seems to me, Doctor, that there is much to be work out regarding
yellow fever, past and present, that the best we can do at this time is
to guess and that is where I would leave the question of origin of
yellow fever.

I wish I could interest you in the matter of suggesting to our Board
to furnish a paleopatholgist to work here in Mexico for a few years. Many
archeologist, including your friend Morely, are agreed that such a move would
be productive of good results.

I greatly appreciate your sending me this MSS. and have truly enjoy-
ed reading it. My regret is that I can not offer you real constructive critic-
ism of same.

Doctor Scannell as you know has left Mexico to accompany Doctor
White to Brazil and therefore there was not time to shown him the MSS.
before his departure. You mention in your letter that a section of
the Mss. has been sent to Dr. Martinez. I would be glad to see this if you
can send it to me.

The month od June passed without a case of y.f. and the outlook
is good.
With all good wishes, I am,
div1.closer:
very sincerely yours, M E Connor. Dr. H.R. Carter,
2121 California St. N.W.
Washington D.C.
